componenttext: For the next calendar year. So it's effective January of next year.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kurt, can you just talk on the International a bit. I understand the seasonal but you were talking about the weakness this quarter. We saw a 500-basis point improvement last quarter, this quarter you note it was 280. Before the downturn, we saw margins in
componenttext: Kurt, can you just talk on the International a bit. I understand the seasonal but you were talking about the weakness this quarter. We saw a 500-basis point improvement last quarter, this quarter you note it was 280. Before the downturn, we saw margins in that 17% to 19% range. So just is there something else going on on the International side, is there pricing? Are there costs coming back online? Can you talk on the International side for a couple of minutes?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken, we were pleased with our Q3 results. Clearly, Q2 was an exceptional quarter for us, very strong growth out of Asia. We were over 40% growth in all of Asia last quarter. That moderated to over 30. So a little bit of tempering in the rate of growt
componenttext: Yes, Ken, we were pleased with our Q3 results. Clearly, Q2 was an exceptional quarter for us, very strong growth out of Asia. We were over 40% growth in all of Asia last quarter. That moderated to over 30. So a little bit of tempering in the rate of growth. The currency also, clearly, if you look at what the euro has done over the last three months was a bit of a drag. But this is -- we are within $9 million of the most profitable quarter ever for Q3 in International. So we're still showing some substantial profit improvements. They were up 34%. We won't continue to compound the 50% growth forever in our profits. But we feel pretty good. We think the yields are stable. As we said, currency was a little bit of a headwind, and Q3 is always a little dicey. But we do see -- we're looking for -- approaching 18% in the fourth quarter. We did warn you last quarter that comps get a little tougher, especially into Q4 because of some of the disruption that happened in November and December last year with international supply chains.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll always, Ken, going to have the weaker margins in Q3 with so much of our business in Europe. And Europe, as you know, pretty well shuts down for the month of August, so we're pleased. We're kind of right on target with where we thought we'd be.
componenttext: We'll always, Ken, going to have the weaker margins in Q3 with so much of our business in Europe. And Europe, as you know, pretty well shuts down for the month of August, so we're pleased. We're kind of right on target with where we thought we'd be.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, Ken, maybe just one other point I guess. We've talked a little bit about this alignment of our Forwarding and Supply Chain and International. And what you saw this quarter was the Forwarding group excelling in an environment of softening rates and pe
componenttext: Hey, Ken, maybe just one other point I guess. We've talked a little bit about this alignment of our Forwarding and Supply Chain and International. And what you saw this quarter was the Forwarding group excelling in an environment of softening rates and perhaps, a little less profit to the airline, which shows up in our package for cargo carry. So there is that give-and-take as market rates go up and down. In one quarter, the International Package will benefit perhaps in the next quarter as rates moderate, we capture that on the Forwarding side.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly, a follow up on yields overall. Your Ground yield is up over 3%. I know pricing was a big focus for you. How far along in this process do you think you are in terms of, at least, that first go around on touching those contracts where you kind of sa
componenttext: Lastly, a follow up on yields overall. Your Ground yield is up over 3%. I know pricing was a big focus for you. How far along in this process do you think you are in terms of, at least, that first go around on touching those contracts where you kind of said to your sales force price now matters, including revenue and volumes. So let's go readdress some of those contracts we'd looked at during the downturn. How far along in the process do you think we are?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're in the middle innings. Clearly, we talked about this as a priority, but it also takes time to work through. Every customer is different. But now we feel very good about it. It's been a priority. Clearly, Scott has reinforced that through the
componenttext: I think we're in the middle innings. Clearly, we talked about this as a priority, but it also takes time to work through. Every customer is different. But now we feel very good about it. It's been a priority. Clearly, Scott has reinforced that through the sales force on our operating units, and we are pleased to see our ability to execute it. And also, customers understanding that there is a need for improved rates after the last couple of years we've had.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the progress has been impressive, considering the economy has been moderate at best. So it's not been an easy economy to do this in.
componenttext: I think the progress has been impressive, considering the economy has been moderate at best. So it's not been an easy economy to do this in.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tom Wadewitz with JPMorgan.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The pricing, Ken asked you a little bit about the pricing. I wonder if you could get maybe a little bit more granular in terms of, I don't know if you want to talk in sequential, what your pricing might have been in Domestic, Ground and Air, third quarter
componenttext: The pricing, Ken asked you a little bit about the pricing. I wonder if you could get maybe a little bit more granular in terms of, I don't know if you want to talk in sequential, what your pricing might have been in Domestic, Ground and Air, third quarter versus second? Obviously, there are a lot of moving pieces in the yield numbers in fuel and mix and weight and so forth. But I don't know if you want to talk sequentially or year-over-year, but can you give us some numbers behind the base pricing in Ground and Air?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in absolute terms, we are seeing good solid growth in base pricing for both Ground and Air. Air has actually improved more substantially since that was flat just a couple of quarters ago. Fuel surcharge was less of an impact this quarter, whereas in
componenttext: Yes, in absolute terms, we are seeing good solid growth in base pricing for both Ground and Air. Air has actually improved more substantially since that was flat just a couple of quarters ago. Fuel surcharge was less of an impact this quarter, whereas in Q2 it was significant for the Air anyway. So there's been a significant reduction at least in the year-over-year change for fuel surcharge. So we see this really as a gradual story, Tom. That we are seeing not dramatic changes quarter-over-quarter, but continuous changes in base rates. And it's great to see the Air business a little firmer and at the same time, we are seeing sustainable increases in the Ground.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look to the 2011, you mentioned a couple of different items or maybe the bigger items on the costs side was pension and then 401(k). What about, I guess, inflation in the wage side and then the incentive comp? Are you close to 100% payout on the
componenttext: When you look to the 2011, you mentioned a couple of different items or maybe the bigger items on the costs side was pension and then 401(k). What about, I guess, inflation in the wage side and then the incentive comp? Are you close to 100% payout on the incentive comp this year so there's not much of a further step up? Or is that an issue that's material to consider on incentive payout in 2011?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say, Tom, that's one of the things that's impressive about this profit we've shown this year, is we have accrued certainly normal incentive pay. So you wouldnt expect a big change in incentive pay in 2011.
componenttext: No, I'd say, Tom, that's one of the things that's impressive about this profit we've shown this year, is we have accrued certainly normal incentive pay. So you wouldnt expect a big change in incentive pay in 2011.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In fact, we'll be announcing that internally today. But no, we're back to a normal burn rate. I think wages will increase, but if we get moderate growth then the impact of a mix of employees, new employees actually helps to mitigate those increases.
componenttext: Yes. In fact, we'll be announcing that internally today. But no, we're back to a normal burn rate. I think wages will increase, but if we get moderate growth then the impact of a mix of employees, new employees actually helps to mitigate those increases. So we feel pretty good that actually wages will be a tailwind for us next year, unless growth really grinds to a halt.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're still into Ed's question earlier. Running about 3.6% average wage rate increase in the third quarter and still showed, due to the productivity, that the comp and benefits up only 1%, so we're doing a good job. If we get growth, as Kurt referred
componenttext: Yes, we're still into Ed's question earlier. Running about 3.6% average wage rate increase in the third quarter and still showed, due to the productivity, that the comp and benefits up only 1%, so we're doing a good job. If we get growth, as Kurt referred to, we certainly will bring that average wage rate deal down.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Scott Malat of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Scott Malat of Goldman Sachs.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask you about -- one of your competitors talking about adjusting their dimensional weight pricing. Are you making any similar changes and what could be the impact for that?
componenttext: Wanted to ask you about -- one of your competitors talking about adjusting their dimensional weight pricing. Are you making any similar changes and what could be the impact for that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've not announced any changes for pricing yet. Clearly, we're evaluating the whole range of our rate strategies going into next year. It's likely we'll announce that either in late October or early November. Cubic space does drive capacity substantially
componenttext: We've not announced any changes for pricing yet. Clearly, we're evaluating the whole range of our rate strategies going into next year. It's likely we'll announce that either in late October or early November. Cubic space does drive capacity substantially in our aircraft. The vast majority of lanes are cubic limited rather than weight limited. And on the ground, it's a little less of an issue. But we're looking at a wide array of cost drivers and trying to decide what's appropriate for rate changes.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, just as a follow up. In the past, you've helped us think through things in terms of domestic pricing about tuck-in retention bids versus new business conversion bids. Have you been seeing less retention bids in Domestic Package? Or just what hav
componenttext: And then, just as a follow up. In the past, you've helped us think through things in terms of domestic pricing about tuck-in retention bids versus new business conversion bids. Have you been seeing less retention bids in Domestic Package? Or just what have the trends been there and how should we think about this?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say, clearly as the economy has gotten better, we are seeing less retention bids and certainly more conversion bids. So that's a healthy trend for UPS.
componenttext: I'd say, clearly as the economy has gotten better, we are seeing less retention bids and certainly more conversion bids. So that's a healthy trend for UPS.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Bill Greene of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Bill Greene of Morgan Stanley.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just in terms of the trend on the Domestic side, B2C. Could you just kind of go through with us, kind of quickly the growth rates there versus B2B?
componenttext: First, just in terms of the trend on the Domestic side, B2C. Could you just kind of go through with us, kind of quickly the growth rates there versus B2B?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are seeing B2C continue to outperform the B2B; both were positive in the quarter. But the consumer is continuing to take advantage of remote, distance-based purchasing. The Internet component of a lot of retailers continues to show good growth whe
componenttext: Yes, we are seeing B2C continue to outperform the B2B; both were positive in the quarter. But the consumer is continuing to take advantage of remote, distance-based purchasing. The Internet component of a lot of retailers continues to show good growth where the bricks-and-mortar is a little more stagnant. But this is also, in some ways, also a B2B led recovery. And so, we are seeing good activity in some of the industrial sectors, the technology sectors have been particularly strong. So on the commercial side, that's moving well. And the real validation of that is the strong growth in our Next Day Package, which is a very strongly B2B related.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: But correct me if I'm wrong, the growth rates in B2B were faster in the first half right, than B2C?
componenttext: But correct me if I'm wrong, the growth rates in B2B were faster in the first half right, than B2C?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, but they converged basically. They were very close. Now that's [indiscernible].
componenttext: No, but they converged basically. They were very close. Now that's [indiscernible].

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then UPS basic, how big a deal is that for you guys now in terms of size or maybe on a relative sizing?
componenttext: And then UPS basic, how big a deal is that for you guys now in terms of size or maybe on a relative sizing?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't release the exact details on it; it's part of a comprehensive solution. But at the basic is most attractive for the lightweight residential shipments, and that's where we inject into the post office. So that is an area of strong growth. But
componenttext: Yes, we don't release the exact details on it; it's part of a comprehensive solution. But at the basic is most attractive for the lightweight residential shipments, and that's where we inject into the post office. So that is an area of strong growth. But typically, it's related to a much broader contract with the customer.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's an important piece of the puzzle.
componenttext: It's an important piece of the puzzle.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Campbell of Thompson, Davis & Co.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Campbell of Thompson, Davis & Co.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I heard what you said about International profitability in-house. I know which side you are, but it's down from the first quarter, and exchange rates have an impact on costs as well. So I'm just trying to figure out, first of all, in the International, wh
componenttext: I heard what you said about International profitability in-house. I know which side you are, but it's down from the first quarter, and exchange rates have an impact on costs as well. So I'm just trying to figure out, first of all, in the International, what's going on? If it continues to be flat, pretty soon you're not going to be satisfied with that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I wouldn't worry about that. I mean Q3 for us anyway with the strong concentration in Europe has always been the weakest quarter. There's a lot of businesses that go on holiday for several weeks in August. So that's a very typical historical trend.
componenttext: David, I wouldn't worry about that. I mean Q3 for us anyway with the strong concentration in Europe has always been the weakest quarter. There's a lot of businesses that go on holiday for several weeks in August. So that's a very typical historical trend. I mean our profits were up over 30% year-over-year. I think that's more the indication. Clearly, the currency is a bit of a headwind right now. And especially, with the euro plummeting and then gradually coming back, it has been a little disruptive. But no, we don't see things stagnating by any means in the International arena.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: An example, David, in the currency though, currency in Europe. All the revenue would be in euros. A big piece of the costs are airplane-related, line-haul related, which are in dollars. So it's a contribution between euro denominated revenue and euro deno
componenttext: An example, David, in the currency though, currency in Europe. All the revenue would be in euros. A big piece of the costs are airplane-related, line-haul related, which are in dollars. So it's a contribution between euro denominated revenue and euro denominated costs. There's a big gap there. So it does have more of an impact, plus we're very profitable in International.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the second question in International, how do you feel about the fourth quarter in Forwarding? Do you seeing a tonnage peak versus the third quarter? How does the usual seasonal peak look at this point; you're almost through October?
componenttext: And the second question in International, how do you feel about the fourth quarter in Forwarding? Do you seeing a tonnage peak versus the third quarter? How does the usual seasonal peak look at this point; you're almost through October?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, well Q3 was primarily an ocean peak issue and we did see a decent ocean peak. Although frankly, it didn't last quite as long as normal. So that wrapped up a little earlier in the summer than is typical. We do expect to see a seasonal peak fo
componenttext: Yes, I think, well Q3 was primarily an ocean peak issue and we did see a decent ocean peak. Although frankly, it didn't last quite as long as normal. So that wrapped up a little earlier in the summer than is typical. We do expect to see a seasonal peak for the Air Freight certainly. Although we don't think it will reach some of the frenzy that it did in Q4 of last year where there were pallets of freight left on the runway in some cases because of increased demand and reduced capacity.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: What could change that, obviously, is consumer demand. If consumer demand is a little stronger than the customers are thinking right now, then that could obviously drive air freight.
componenttext: What could change that, obviously, is consumer demand. If consumer demand is a little stronger than the customers are thinking right now, then that could obviously drive air freight.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Robin Byde of HSBC.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Robin Byde of HSBC.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on International pricing. I just noticed your domestic yields were pretty weak again as at Q2. So my guess is that it doesn't look seasonality related. Is this still the dilution impact from the Turkey acquisition?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on International pricing. I just noticed your domestic yields were pretty weak again as at Q2. So my guess is that it doesn't look seasonality related. Is this still the dilution impact from the Turkey acquisition?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well certainly, yes. Turkey is still a piece of that. We did have the July was before the Turkey overlap, so that was a significant piece. Yields are basically stable in the domestic. We have been growing substantially, profits are good. So the market we
componenttext: Well certainly, yes. Turkey is still a piece of that. We did have the July was before the Turkey overlap, so that was a significant piece. Yields are basically stable in the domestic. We have been growing substantially, profits are good. So the market we think is stable. Domestic, although it's hard to draw any broad-based, because it's a wide array of countries. But we are seeing, Robin, substantial, almost surprising continued growth in Europe, both on the Domestic and the Export side. Canada and Mexico, both of our Domestic operations there continue to show good results. So, customer-by-customer, there are some challenging pricing environments. But we feel pretty good that the market is stable.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The weakness in your international export yield this quarter, is that just all about seasonality? Or is there something else going on there?
componenttext: The weakness in your international export yield this quarter, is that just all about seasonality? Or is there something else going on there?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, if you adjust out currency, actually export yields are up 3%. I mean there is some seasonal cyclicality. But if you look at year-over-year, we're up 3%. So I think things once again are pretty stable on the pricing across the globe. UPS's value propos
componenttext: No, if you adjust out currency, actually export yields are up 3%. I mean there is some seasonal cyclicality. But if you look at year-over-year, we're up 3%. So I think things once again are pretty stable on the pricing across the globe. UPS's value proposition continues to get stronger, with our balanced capabilities across the globe. We can really bring things to customers that others can't. And that allows us to have some pricing power.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we saw a little stronger mix of strategic accounts in the quarter where some of the bigger multinationals probably shipped a higher proportion and that drives, obviously a little bit of impact on yield.
componenttext: So we saw a little stronger mix of strategic accounts in the quarter where some of the bigger multinationals probably shipped a higher proportion and that drives, obviously a little bit of impact on yield.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman of Sterne Agee & Leach.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman of Sterne Agee & Leach.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions on the cost side. If I look at depreciation expense, whether I'm looking at it on a percent of revenue basis or per package basis and other expense on the same basis, those came a little lower than expected. I think the other expense was dow
componenttext: Two questions on the cost side. If I look at depreciation expense, whether I'm looking at it on a percent of revenue basis or per package basis and other expense on the same basis, those came a little lower than expected. I think the other expense was down almost $170 million sequentially. The questions are, are the gains in sale offsetting the depreciation or is that more of a sustainable run rate? And on the other expense, I know you mentioned the restructuring, but how much of this is going to be permanent change and is this the run rate of that expense level? Or should I think of it something maybe closer to $900 million, $950 million?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, the schedule that we have on other expense, the other other that shows the $170 million decline is directly impacted by the gain of sale of real estate that we had. That was $109 million before tax.
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, the schedule that we have on other expense, the other other that shows the $170 million decline is directly impacted by the gain of sale of real estate that we had. That was $109 million before tax.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I net that out, it's more like $60 million, $70 million? And are there increased gains on sales, because I know the PP&E sales are up this year?
componenttext: So I net that out, it's more like $60 million, $70 million? And are there increased gains on sales, because I know the PP&E sales are up this year?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that was the most notable. We have retired quite a few vehicles, which has impacted the balance sheet a little bit. So we are in the process of taking part of our CapEx to take older vehicles out of the Fleet. But in general, no, the only major blip
componenttext: Well, that was the most notable. We have retired quite a few vehicles, which has impacted the balance sheet a little bit. So we are in the process of taking part of our CapEx to take older vehicles out of the Fleet. But in general, no, the only major blip in that segment was the sale of the real estate. But some of the benefits, some of the cost tightening that we've done, bad debt is down substantially, that shows up there, supply reduction and some of those things. Depreciation is at a pretty stable rate I think. If you go back and you look at the last few quarters, there's nothing in there. That's a good run rate, Jeff, for that.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from the line of Justin Yagerman of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Justin Yagerman of Deutsche Bank.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wanted to dig in a little bit on your commentary around Q4 Air Freight peaking, get a sense of what you guys are seeing right now? How does the capacity situation, in terms of lift out of Asia, stack up versus last year? And then I mean in the event that
componenttext: Wanted to dig in a little bit on your commentary around Q4 Air Freight peaking, get a sense of what you guys are seeing right now? How does the capacity situation, in terms of lift out of Asia, stack up versus last year? And then I mean in the event that we did get a boost in consumer demand, I guess, is there enough capacity right now to move that demand? Or do you think that we'd find ourselves in a similar situation to last year?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say, generally, there is more capacity than there was a year ago. I wouldn't say a lot more capacity but there is more capacity. For example, UPS, we've added several flights, a couple of flights per day from China to the U.S. and to Europe. So we've
componenttext: I'd say, generally, there is more capacity than there was a year ago. I wouldn't say a lot more capacity but there is more capacity. For example, UPS, we've added several flights, a couple of flights per day from China to the U.S. and to Europe. So we've done that. Some of our competitors have done that. But I still think there's not certainly excess capacity by any means. And if there is more consumer demand, we'll still seek it, could be a spike later in the year.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think back to Scott's comments on inventory, I think one of the recurring themes we've seen is that at least at the retail side, inventories remain pretty tight. Customers decided not to move everything via ocean early. There were some that did, but I t
componenttext: I think back to Scott's comments on inventory, I think one of the recurring themes we've seen is that at least at the retail side, inventories remain pretty tight. Customers decided not to move everything via ocean early. There were some that did, but I think there is some potential leverage there. If this holiday season comes in a little better, it could end up being a pretty good blooming rate for the growth.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a related question; given the Logistics that it would take to move things in an expedited fashion if that were to occur. Do you have customers that are talking to you about how their CapEx plans, or their ordering trends might change if midterm e
componenttext: And then a related question; given the Logistics that it would take to move things in an expedited fashion if that were to occur. Do you have customers that are talking to you about how their CapEx plans, or their ordering trends might change if midterm elections go the way that people are expecting them to go? Do you have any insight into the thought process of the corporates you do business with post that time period?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think clearly businesses are watching the elections, are concerned about tax strat policies and some of those things. As to whether it would have a rapid impact on capital plans or inventory levels, probably not. I think that will be more consumer deman
componenttext: I think clearly businesses are watching the elections, are concerned about tax strat policies and some of those things. As to whether it would have a rapid impact on capital plans or inventory levels, probably not. I think that will be more consumer demand driven.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next in queue is Nate Brochmann of William Blair and Company.
componenttext: Next in queue is Nate Brochmann of William Blair and Company.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask kind of a similar question but a little bit bigger picture regarding Asia. Obviously, the other day, there was a lot of talk regarding currency, interest rates, et cetera, and what that does in terms of growth out of that region. It still
componenttext: I wanted to ask kind of a similar question but a little bit bigger picture regarding Asia. Obviously, the other day, there was a lot of talk regarding currency, interest rates, et cetera, and what that does in terms of growth out of that region. It still seems to me that regardless of what happens, there's going to be a lot of activity. I was wondering kind of what you're seeing bigger picture from your perspective? And I know you're making some additional investments over there, if you could talk a little more in detail with that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I see a lot of the trends we've seen the last several years continuing. I think that although when you get towards midterm elections in the U.S., you hear a lot of talks of protectionism. I think the administration supports trade. And I think that when we
componenttext: I see a lot of the trends we've seen the last several years continuing. I think that although when you get towards midterm elections in the U.S., you hear a lot of talks of protectionism. I think the administration supports trade. And I think that when we get Congress back together, we'll support trade and we'll solve these issues with China. So I'm very bullish on the outlook for Asia moving forward. I think there will be blips along the way, where people will talk at trade wars, but I don't see it happening. I look at again at the U.S., the U.S. businesses, 96% of our consumers are outside of the United States. We need to promote trade going forward. So I see there will be ups and downs. There will be times when China will be challenged. But I think in general, we see strong growth across Asia moving forward.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And clearly, our strategies are to capitalize on that. We continue to expand our infrastructure, increase our capabilities and supply chain and freight, and look for growth opportunities.
componenttext: And clearly, our strategies are to capitalize on that. We continue to expand our infrastructure, increase our capabilities and supply chain and freight, and look for growth opportunities.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The unknown is how fast the consumer base will grow in places like China and India. We know they're going to grow, but will it grow over the next five years, next 10 years, next 20 years, we'll see. But clearly, there'll be more consumption down in that p
componenttext: The unknown is how fast the consumer base will grow in places like China and India. We know they're going to grow, but will it grow over the next five years, next 10 years, next 20 years, we'll see. But clearly, there'll be more consumption down in that part of the world looking forward.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to kind of just follow up on that. How do you think about your strategy then in terms of that unknown consumer demand in that region and as manufacturing moves from the coast then inland, how do you think strategically about your rate of investment to
componenttext: And to kind of just follow up on that. How do you think about your strategy then in terms of that unknown consumer demand in that region and as manufacturing moves from the coast then inland, how do you think strategically about your rate of investment to kind of tackle that movement?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're going to be aggressive there. Again, we've got a wonderful balance sheet, and we look for those opportunities to invest. And most of our business is portable anyway, and a lot of it is airplanes and you move with the businesses. So I think that as m
componenttext: We're going to be aggressive there. Again, we've got a wonderful balance sheet, and we look for those opportunities to invest. And most of our business is portable anyway, and a lot of it is airplanes and you move with the businesses. So I think that as more and more moves to western China, we'll be there right with the customers.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good example. We're the only major competitor in our segment that has two air hubs in China. So we're very well-positioned with Shanghai and the Shenzhen hubs to distribute goods around China. We're continuing to expand our alliances and do de
componenttext: Yes, it's a good example. We're the only major competitor in our segment that has two air hubs in China. So we're very well-positioned with Shanghai and the Shenzhen hubs to distribute goods around China. We're continuing to expand our alliances and do deeper investments. We're in the process of opening a healthcare distribution facility in Singapore. So clearly, we are focused on that. We'll do it in typical UPS fashion, which is with a mind towards both growth and return on capital. But it is a high priority for us.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Brooklier of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Brooklier of Piper Jaffray.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Quick question, pilot furloughs, where are you in that process? What was the impact on third quarter? And how should we think about cost impact from pilot furloughs into fourth quarter?
componenttext: Quick question, pilot furloughs, where are you in that process? What was the impact on third quarter? And how should we think about cost impact from pilot furloughs into fourth quarter?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're at right now, Matt, is we're at about 109 pilots furloughs. Right now, the announced goal is 230. But we've actually taken what we call a timeout, a break in this. One, we want to see how business is improving. International business is gettin
componenttext: Well, we're at right now, Matt, is we're at about 109 pilots furloughs. Right now, the announced goal is 230. But we've actually taken what we call a timeout, a break in this. One, we want to see how business is improving. International business is getting better. There's also some proposed rule-making out there regarding pilot rest hours, pilot fatigue that we really want to understand. The impact of that is not going to take place immediately. But we want to work with the industry and with our pilots, and with the government to figure out what will those rules be and will that change staffing requirements. So it really made an awful lot of sense at this point in time to halt, put a stop to the furlough until we understand the implications of the rule-making. And then probably, by the first of the year or early into 2011, we'll have a better view of where we go from here.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question, Domestic Ground packages, you guys saw a nice uptick in terms of the volume growth rate. Wanted to know if there was anything strategically that you're doing different in terms of driving volume growth in that business? I also noticed tha
componenttext: Second question, Domestic Ground packages, you guys saw a nice uptick in terms of the volume growth rate. Wanted to know if there was anything strategically that you're doing different in terms of driving volume growth in that business? I also noticed that sequentially, your yields were down modestly in that product. I don't know if I'm reading too deeply into that data point, but can you talk a little bit about that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're continuing to work as hard as we can to add value to customers. Clearly, we have a big focus on -- with the deployment of our field marketing groups to understanding unique industries and unique customer needs in bringing them more comprehensive Log
componenttext: We're continuing to work as hard as we can to add value to customers. Clearly, we have a big focus on -- with the deployment of our field marketing groups to understanding unique industries and unique customer needs in bringing them more comprehensive Logistics solutions. So we think that is a great catalyst for growth. On the yield side, really, the core of base rate trends actually are stronger. The fuel surcharges that accounts really for the totality of any revenue per piece differences.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from Art Hatfield of Morgan Keegan and Company.
componenttext: And we have a question from Art Hatfield of Morgan Keegan and Company.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't recall hearing you mention what CapEx was in the quarter. If you did, I apologize. And secondly, can you say anything about how we should think about that over the next year or so?
componenttext: I don't recall hearing you mention what CapEx was in the quarter. If you did, I apologize. And secondly, can you say anything about how we should think about that over the next year or so?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, basically CapEx year-to-date is a little over $1 billion. We've got it for the year to be at about $1.8 billion. We're probably going to come in at a little below that. But we're continuing to invest wherever it makes sense. As I mentioned in my prep
componenttext: Yes, basically CapEx year-to-date is a little over $1 billion. We've got it for the year to be at about $1.8 billion. We're probably going to come in at a little below that. But we're continuing to invest wherever it makes sense. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks there, our cash position continues to be strong. We're generating substantial amount of free cash flow. It's one of the reasons we decided to extend our share repurchases with the S&P changing their outlook to stable. We are very comfortable continuing to reduce our cash to repurchase shares along with investing in the business. So from a cash perspective, all systems are go. We are going to continue to buy aircraft and do targeted investments in those areas we need added capacity. But we do expect CapEx to remain below its historical normals based on the fact that we've really got a modern new air fleet. We've retired all of our older generation aircraft. We've got a Worldport hub that's complete. We've got major hubs in China. We've got good capacity in Europe. So we're in a great position to look for new growth opportunities and invest in those when they come around.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Ross of Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Ross of Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question on export growth for small- to medium-sized businesses that you're working with those customers to try to stimulate more exports from them. Wondering what kind of segments that would benefit most at UPS? Would that be the International Frei
componenttext: First question on export growth for small- to medium-sized businesses that you're working with those customers to try to stimulate more exports from them. Wondering what kind of segments that would benefit most at UPS? Would that be the International Freight Forwarding segment, your International Package segment, your Domestic Package segment?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say all of the above. But I think clearly, the International Package side would be the biggest beneficiary right now, and we're making good progress. We've identified 9,000 customers who ship to just one -- export to one country. We're trying to get t
componenttext: I'd say all of the above. But I think clearly, the International Package side would be the biggest beneficiary right now, and we're making good progress. We've identified 9,000 customers who ship to just one -- export to one country. We're trying to get those 9,000 customers to go to at least a second country. And we're making some good progress. We did show double-digit U.S. export growth again in the last quarter. Trends remain strong there. But it's to helping to educate small- and medium-sized enterprises of the value and the ease. And thats a lot of our Logistics campaign, just trying to -- supposed to educate the SMEs on -- they can use UPS as a partner to handle some of the business differences, cultural differences, custom regulation differences of other countries. It seems to be working.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, at UPS Freight, you mentioned you were still unhappy with the margins there. To get them to where you want them, is it a function of you need more volume because you have excess capacity in the network? Is it just yields, do you need price? Or i
componenttext: And then, at UPS Freight, you mentioned you were still unhappy with the margins there. To get them to where you want them, is it a function of you need more volume because you have excess capacity in the network? Is it just yields, do you need price? Or is it improving your overall operations and productivity still?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean it's -- the majority of it is the environment. I mean LTL is a still very tough place to be. The price environment is beginning to firm, but there were a couple of years there was it was extremely challenging. We've tried to stick to the high road
componenttext: I mean it's -- the majority of it is the environment. I mean LTL is a still very tough place to be. The price environment is beginning to firm, but there were a couple of years there was it was extremely challenging. We've tried to stick to the high road because we're making deep investments in technology and in the network enhancements. So we've been focused on pricing and targeting those markets that make sense to us. So I'd say the vast majority of the Freight headwinds are market related. We do continue to see great results though in bringing technology and ease-of-use to the middle market for the LTL segment. We think that really, this industry has been under invested in. We know that one of our big competitors is getting ready to go through some restructuring and realignment. We've already heard from some customers that are concerned about that. So we're going to stay focused. Our operations are working well. We've got an integrated regional and long-distance network, national. So we've already done the hard work of providing a single carrier that can cover any geography across the continent. So we feel pretty good where we are. It'd be nice if the overall segment was in better shape. That does though give us a great tailwind over the next couple of years for supply chain and freight, when the freight segment really begins contributing, we've got even better results ahead.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: I wanted to come back to the comment about the other expense. You said maybe some lower bad debt in there even after you strip out the real estate gain though, it does look like its running at a lower rate than normal, especially as a percent of revenue. Is that something you expect to continue?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in a modest sense, the year-over-year comparisons, there's some slight expenses last year that were one-time, but it's $20 million, $30 million. No, it's just a comprehensive reduction of expenses. Our claims expenses are down as our quality
componenttext: Well, I think in a modest sense, the year-over-year comparisons, there's some slight expenses last year that were one-time, but it's $20 million, $30 million. No, it's just a comprehensive reduction of expenses. Our claims expenses are down as our quality continues to improve. Negotiation through our procurement on supplies, telecom expenses, you name it. It's just some of that is just the fruit of a lot of hard work. Certainly, the one-time event of the sale of the real estate did give us a big boost. But it's an area we're going to continue to focus on. It does fluctuate a little bit, but there's nothing outsized as far as anything that distorted it, other than what we've talked about.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've heard from a number of the trucking companies that the freight market broadly seemed to slow down towards the end of the third quarter and has slowed still into October. Have you sensed that, in any of your businesses, either domestically or interna
componenttext: We've heard from a number of the trucking companies that the freight market broadly seemed to slow down towards the end of the third quarter and has slowed still into October. Have you sensed that, in any of your businesses, either domestically or internationally?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we've seen any change at all from what we saw in the third quarter. I think October is moving along t a steady pace. Again, we're in a moderate economy. We're probably a 2%, 2.5% type of economy and I don't suspect any change over the last s
componenttext: I don't think we've seen any change at all from what we saw in the third quarter. I think October is moving along t a steady pace. Again, we're in a moderate economy. We're probably a 2%, 2.5% type of economy and I don't suspect any change over the last several months.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the most notable thing, just looking at our reported results as you do have some gains with the calendar. That third quarter did get a benefit from the overlap against the 4th of July last year and our fourth quarter volume that we will repor
componenttext: Yes, I think the most notable thing, just looking at our reported results as you do have some gains with the calendar. That third quarter did get a benefit from the overlap against the 4th of July last year and our fourth quarter volume that we will report will, on an average daily basis, be muted by the fact that we have one extra day between Christmas and New Year's without much added volume. So if you take those two out, then I think youve got a pretty core stable trend, and that's what we're seeing in the market.

componenttext: Yes, I'm going to turn it over to Scott for some closing comments.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and thanks for everybody for attending the conference today. But I'm really pleased that we showed superior results across all segments, and we did this in a modest economy. And year-to-date operating profit, in both International Package, a
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and thanks for everybody for attending the conference today. But I'm really pleased that we showed superior results across all segments, and we did this in a modest economy. And year-to-date operating profit, in both International Package, and Supply Chain and Freight were the best ever. And that says an awful lot in an economy that's really is not recovering at a fast pace.
And despite some of the questions on International, they were the best nine months we've ever had in International. I'm extremely bullish going forward in that segment. In U.S., Domestic operating profit is up 50%, 77% for the quarter, so it's extremely strong growth in that area.
As Kurt mentioned, we generated $3.5 billion free cash flow for the first nine months, extremely strong. We raised our full-year guidance more than 50% in growth over the last year than we expected, a good strong fourth quarter. And I'm extremely confident we're on our way back to the high levels of profitability that weve demonstrated in the past. So weve got a lot of confidence, we're going in the right direction. Thanks so much for attending today.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Steven, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the UPS Investor Relations Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now it is my pleasure to tu
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Steven, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the UPS Investor Relations Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now it is my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mr. Andy Dolny, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. In a moment, Scott Davis, our CEO; and Kurt Kuehn, our CFO, will discuss third quarter results and expectations going forward. Before they begin, however, I want to review the Safe Harbor language.Som
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. In a moment, Scott Davis, our CEO; and Kurt Kuehn, our CFO, will discuss third quarter results and expectations going forward. Before they begin, however, I want to review the Safe Harbor language.
Some of the comments we'll make today are forward-looking statements that address our expectations for the future performance or results of operations of the company. These anticipated results are subject to risk and uncertainties, which are described in detail in our 2009 form 10-K and 2010 10-Q reports. These reports are available on the UPS Investor Relations website, or from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Today's call is being webcast and will also be available on the UPS Investor Relations website.
In our earnings announcement today, you'll notice that we recognized a gain of $109 million on the sale of real estate. This provided an after-tax benefit of $61 million, or $0.06 per share. Excluding this transaction, diluted earnings per share for the third quarter were $0.93. In their remarks today, Scott and Kurt will refer to UPS's third quarter 2010 results, excluding the impact of this gain. Additionally, all 2010 full-year references and comparisons to 2009 will refer to adjusted results. We believe this is the most accurate picture of the company's performance.
Reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures and free cash flow, which is a non-GAAP financial measure, are explained in the schedules that accompanied our earnings news release. The schedules are also available on the UPS Investor Relations website in the financial section.
To begin our review, I'll turn the program over to Scott.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good morning, everyone. The results that UPS announced today are another step in getting back to peak earnings and historical margins. Considering the slow growth economic environment that exists, I find it extremely encouraging to see o
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good morning, everyone. The results that UPS announced today are another step in getting back to peak earnings and historical margins. Considering the slow growth economic environment that exists, I find it extremely encouraging to see our three segments hitting on all cylinders. UPS has run the top of their game, generating significant operating profit improvement. This validates our comprehensive supply chain strategy. 
As for the economy, over the past few months, experts have reduced expectations for fourth quarter economic output. Including their outlook for U.S. GEP where modest growth is still expected. When it comes to inventory levels, there is a lot of debate. Some inventory building has occurred this year, but due to the low inventory-to-sales ratios and other indices, it appears there may still be room for additional restocking.
During the quarter, we announced a new global communications platform. Given the complexities of today's marketplace, we designed our advertising campaign to spotlight the power of Logistics. Our experience of worldwide capabilities make UPS uniquely qualified to provide solutions to our customers throughout their supply chain.
We don't just talk about global trade, we make it happen. UPS provides new tools to customers that help them expand their business like UPS Import Control, a solution that allows them to better manage inbound shipments. In addition, we continue to enhance our paperless invoice technology. UPS introduced this to the market more than two years ahead of the competition. This tool now provides expedited customs clearance in 92 countries, more than any competitor. Not only have we added tools to help businesses compete on a global basis, but we are growing our footprint so they can grow theirs. 
UPS continues to expand in important emerging markets, announcing a joint venture in Indonesia with J&E this quarter. And that's on the heels of the alliances announced earlier this year in Malaysia and Vietnam.
In the U.S., to help our customers better manage returns, we now offer a UPS Returns Flexible Access, a low-cost, high-quality service that provides unmatched alternatives to customers. As you can see, UPS is never standing still. In fact, just this month, we opened our first Olympic Logistics center in London. This gives UPS an excellent opportunity to showcase our capabilities to the world.
As the official Logistics provider for the 2012 Olympics, UPS will ensure the world's largest Logistics event goes off without a hitch. Now I would like to take a moment to talk about the UPS team.
During the quarter, we suffered the loss of two UPSers in a tragic plane crash. On behalf of the UPS employees around the world, I wish to extend our deepest sympathy to their families.
I also want to personally thank UPS employees for providing the best service in the industry, going the extra mile to ensure our customers continue to trust UPS with their business. No matter where I go, people comment on how they appreciate the professionalism of UPSers around the world and the quality of our service.
Many times, customers talk about our drivers as an extension of their company. Let me tell you, that makes me very proud of the great team we have here at UPS. Not only our UPSers committed to providing great service, they are also dedicated to their communities.
In July, the United Way recognized UPS and our employees as the first company ever with donations of more than $1 billion. This generosity of our active and retired employees is unmatched. Overall, another great quarter for UPS. We continue to achieve results that exceed expectations. Even though our operating margin is the best in the industry, we are not satisfied. I am confident in our ability to return them to pre-recession levels. We are on the right track. Now let me turn it over to Kurt.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott, and good morning. Well, we had another tremendous quarter, with earnings up almost 70%. Revenue continued to reflect strong growth, up 9% over last year, even with one less working day. These are impressive results, considering the slow pac
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott, and good morning. Well, we had another tremendous quarter, with earnings up almost 70%. Revenue continued to reflect strong growth, up 9% over last year, even with one less working day. These are impressive results, considering the slow pace of the economic recovery.
UPS's operating margin expanded 410 basis points to 12.4%, continuing our rebound towards historic levels. Keep in mind, current margins do reflect reinstated merit increases and growth in incentive compensation that's due to solid business performance.
For the quarter, total comp and benefits increased only 1% on volume growth to 3.3%. This clearly reflects the impact of greater volume, productivity improvements, network enhancements and the U.S. restructuring announced earlier this year. Now let's start our review of the segments, beginning with U.S. Domestic.
Total revenue increased 6.2% to $7.3 billion on average daily volume growth of 3.6%. Daily volume comparisons did benefit somewhat from the 4th of July operating schedule. Ground volume increased 3.9% per day, and UPS Next Day Air was up 3.2%. This is the third consecutive quarter of domestic volume growth, each quarter showing greater year-over-year improvement.
Total revenue per piece grew 4%, with UPS Next Day Air up 7% and Ground improving 3.2%. Yields benefited from our ability to retain a greater portion of the general rate increase and rising fuel surcharges.  Air products also benefited from a more favorable package- to-letter mix and weight per piece, which has continued to improve and is in the latter stages of recovery. 
Operating margin was 12.5%, an increase of 500 basis points due to volume growth, yield gains and significant productivity improvements across the UPS network. Expense was held in check due to effective management of direct labor hours, miles driven, block hours and non-op expense, all in all, a great job by our UPS team.
In July, UPS issued our most recent sustainability report and announced an ambitious new target for increasing the fuel efficiency of our U.S. automotive fleet by 20%. In September, we purchased an additional 130 hybrid electric vehicles to help us reach that goal. This brings UPS's fleet of alternative fuel vehicles to over 2,000, one of the largest private fleets.  And when it comes to our air fleet, it remains one of the most fuel-efficient in the industry, more than 10 years ahead of any U.S. competitor. 
Now for the International segment, where operating profit climbed 34% to $419 million on 11% growth in revenue.  This profit is within $9 million of our highest third quarter in UPS history in what is typically our most challenging quarter due to the European summer holidays. Total package volume per day improved over 13%, with exports up 12.5% and non-U.S. domestic up 14%. Domestic growth slowed from the previous quarters pace as a result of lapping last year's acquisition in Turkey. However, organic growth still remained robust at 11%.
Export volume growth remained strong in all regions, with Asia once again leading the way with 34% growth. In addition, European export daily volume continued to perform well, increasing 12.5% with balanced growth to all regions of the world.  Export yields improved about 1% as the positive impact of base rate increases and higher fuel surcharges were offset by currency. On a currency neutral basis, export rates improved over 3%.
In-country operations cost per piece declined 2.5% as a result of greater scale, improved productivity and density improvements. Overall, operating margin increased to 15.7%, up 280 basis points. Although the euro-to-dollar relationship was a slight drag.
During the quarter, in our growth through global trade seminars, UPS worked to help small- and medium-size enterprises grow their business and expand their footprint through exports. Now for the Supply Chain and Freight segment, where UPS had a great quarter, hitting a new high in both operating margin and operating profit for this developing segment of our business.
Revenue increased 19%, led by 23% growth in Forwarding and Logistics and continued growth in UPS Freight. Driven primarily by our Forwarding and Logistics businesses, operating profit jumped over 70% to $177 million, with margins reaching 8%, an increase of 250 basis points. The power of our broad portfolio was once again demonstrated in our forwarding unit. The revenue management initiatives and block space agreements we've put in place continue to provide benefits.  We experienced strong revenue growth as we help customers manage their supply chains, offering solutions that include both air freight and small package. 
Margins in the Logistics business approached double digits as a result of our global capabilities, technology and the strength of the UPS brand.  Logistics revenue benefited from high single-digit growth in healthcare and high-tech. 
UPS Freight continued to make progress, with more than 14% increase in revenue. Growth in revenue per hundredweight was again one of the highest in the industry.
During the quarter, we also saw improvements in gross weight hold, weight per shipment and shipments per day. In the ocean freight area of the Forwarding business, we introduced UPS Preferred Less Than Container Loads service. This service provides up to 20% improvement in Time-In-Transit for our customers. Early reaction from the marketplace has been positive.
You know a key strength of the UPS operating model is the ability to generate significant cash. For the first nine months of 2010, our free cash flow was $3.5 billion, this after UPS invested $1 billion in capital expenditures and made pension contributions of more than $1 billion. We also paid dividends of $1.36 billion, reflecting a 4.4% increase, and spent $589 million to repurchase 9.3 million shares.
As a testament to our strong financial performance, S&P recently reaffirmed our rating and revised their outlook for UPS to stable. This enables greater flexibility as we develop our capital allocation strategy. It goes without saying that our first priority is to invest in the business, followed by a combination of dividends and share repurchases. We will also consider accelerated contribution to UPS's pension plans. 
Regarding share repurchases, by the end of the third quarter, we had reached our original target of offsetting the dilution of stock-based compensation. We do intend to go beyond that target, and will continue to purchase stock in the fourth quarter.
For 2011, our plan is to ramp up share repurchases as we increase distributions to shareowners. We will provide more details on expectations for next year during our fourth quarter earnings call. While I'm on the topic of 2011, as a result of our continued momentum, yesterday we announced to our employees that next year, UPS will reinstate our 401(k) match. 
Next, I'd like to discuss our fourth quarter guidance. Expectations for economic output have declined from where they were three months ago, but modest growth is still expected. Looking towards peak season, customer sentiment is mixed but leaning towards cautious optimism.
For the U.S. Domestic segment, we expect the revenue year-over-year growth rate to be slightly better than what we saw in the third quarter. Year-over-year volume trends, however, will be muted by one more working day between Christmas and New Years compared to last year. As a result, we expect average daily volume growth in the fourth quarter of about 1.5% to 2%.
We anticipate that the fourth quarter operating margin will remain strong, at or above the third quarter. In the International segment, we expect volume growth rates to outpace the market, although they will moderate somewhat. 
Last year, if you recall, peak season capacity in the air freight market was extremely tight coming out of Asia, benefiting our International segment in both profit and volume growth.
Against these year-over-year comparisons, we expect high single-digit growth in top line revenue and an operating margin approaching 18%. We do expect a slight currency headwind.
In the Supply Chain and Freight segment, we anticipate the pace of revenue growth to slow due to comparisons to the strong air freight market conditions that existed last year. But margins will remain strong, approaching 7% for the quarter.
Based on our continued momentum, we have raised our full-year 2010 guidance, from the previous range of $3.35 to $3.45, up to a new range of $3.48 to $3.54 per share. This represents more than a 50% increase over last year's results. As you can see, UPS is on our way back to the high levels of profitability that we have demonstrated in the past. The goals and long-term strategies that we have put in place will further widen the gap between UPS and the rest of the competition.
Thanks for your attention, and now Scott and I will be happy to answer your questions.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Gary Chase with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Gary Chase with Barclays Capital.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wondered if you could maybe address what's going on in SCF and obviously, you talked a little bit about it. But at least the way we look at it, there was a very significant uptick in the profitability of that, especially when you look at normal seasonalit
componenttext: Wondered if you could maybe address what's going on in SCF and obviously, you talked a little bit about it. But at least the way we look at it, there was a very significant uptick in the profitability of that, especially when you look at normal seasonality. Can you walk us through what is driving that? And then maybe, talk through obviously, the advertising campaign, now it makes the timing of it seems a little more -- or makes more sense. What's changing that's driving this? And how's your outlook changing about how you might invest in that business looking forward?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, we are certainly pleased with the progress we've made in the Supply Chain and Freight segment. I mean it's been a long-time coming; we began investing deeply in this back in 2000. But what we are seeing basically is the work we've done to create hig
componenttext: Gary, we are certainly pleased with the progress we've made in the Supply Chain and Freight segment. I mean it's been a long-time coming; we began investing deeply in this back in 2000. But what we are seeing basically is the work we've done to create highly aligned capabilities across all modes and across activities is really paying dividends. Year-to-date, this is the most profitable period we've had for Supply Chain and Freight. Actually, it's also that case for International. We were helped certainly in the Forwarding arena with strong demand and also moderating rates. So we reverse some of the margin squeeze that we saw earlier in the year, so that was a great sign. We're also seeing good momentum in our ocean freight. We mentioned the launch of this less-than-container-load service and all of those pieces together really gave us some good capabilities. Logistics really is hitting its stride with us finding those unique services we can bring to high-tech and healthcare. And then UPS Freight had a good solid quarter. Clearly, it's not up to the margins we'd like, but it continues to generate strong revenue growth and great yields. So we're seeing improvement on all fronts.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Gary, I think Kurt said it well. I think we're quite pleased with the Forwarding and Logistics margins, they're at the levels we like to see them at. Clearly, the LTL piece is not there yet. And as that market improves, as we continue to make progress
componenttext: And Gary, I think Kurt said it well. I think we're quite pleased with the Forwarding and Logistics margins, they're at the levels we like to see them at. Clearly, the LTL piece is not there yet. And as that market improves, as we continue to make progress, you're going to see enhanced margins long term in Supply Chain and Freight. The overall advertising campaign geared to Logistics was geared to everything that we do. It's about contract Logistics, it's about freight forwarding, it's about brokerage capabilities, it's about package transportation. So it's about everything we do.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Should we expect that the way you said Forwarding and Logistics must be at the kind of returns that you do like and you always talked about. Is your outlook on capital deployment into that segment different as the result of the progress that you've made?
componenttext: Should we expect that the way you said Forwarding and Logistics must be at the kind of returns that you do like and you always talked about. Is your outlook on capital deployment into that segment different as the result of the progress that you've made?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, clearly we love Logistics. And we'll look for prudent ways to expand the business. Although we've invested a tremendous amount to build a global platform. So we don't need acquisitions for growth. We've got an incredible access to customers. But the
componenttext: Gary, clearly we love Logistics. And we'll look for prudent ways to expand the business. Although we've invested a tremendous amount to build a global platform. So we don't need acquisitions for growth. We've got an incredible access to customers. But there may be some areas, developing countries and others where it makes sense to do tuck-in acquisitions.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And perhaps verticals, there may be a vertical we want to enhance something in the healthcare area. So certainly, that's on the drawing board.
componenttext: And perhaps verticals, there may be a vertical we want to enhance something in the healthcare area. So certainly, that's on the drawing board.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
